Graphical abstract Upgrading bioderived furfurals (furfural, 5-hydroxymethylfurfural) to cyclopentanones (cyclopentanone, 3-hydroxymethylcyclopentanone) and cyclopentanols (cyclopentanol, 3-hydroxymethylcyclopentanol) is a representative bifunctional catalytic process in biomass conversion. Here, a class of Pd/NiMoO4 catalysts (Pd/NiMoO4-Cl, Pd/NiMoO4-AC) with low Pd loading (1.0 wt%) and different Pd dispersion are synthesized. The hydrogenation active sites and acidic sites of catalysts were adjusted by a water-mediated hydrogen spillover process. 56.3–85.3% yields of cyclopentanones and 65.4–85.2% yields of cyclopentanols were obtained by hydrogenative ring-rearrangement route of furfurals over Pd/NiMoO4-Cl and Pd/NiMoO4-AC, respectively. Over-hydrogenated byproducts (tetrahydrofurfuryl alcohol, 2,5-bis(hydroxymethyl)tetrahydrofuran) with a yield above 54% were generated by a full hydrogenation route over Pd/C. The difference in catalytic performance is results from alteration of the adsorption configurations of reactants and the transformation of Lewis acid sites to Brønsted acid sites by hydrogen spillover. This work presents an effective strategy for governing reaction routes and enhancing bifunctional catalysis with a hydrogen spillover mechanism. Keywords Hydrogen spillover Furfurals Adsorption configuration Acid transformation Hydrogenative ring-rearrangement 1 Introduction Biorefining biomass into fine chemicals is a promising route to a sustainable future economy. Bioderived furfural and 5-hydroxymethylfurfural, obtained from the dehydration of pentoses and hexoses, have been considered as the most important biobased platform compounds [1,2]. Because their complex structures contain several functional groups (such as furan ring, carbonyl, and hydroxyl), bifunctional hydrogenation and acid catalysis are common used for upgrading them to various fine chemicals, such as hydrogenative ring-opening to linear polyols (1,2-pentanediol, 1,5-pentanediol, 1,6-hexanediol and 1,2,6-hexanetriol) [3–6], hydrogenative etherification to furan ethers (2-(alkoxymethyl)furan and 2,5-bis(alkoxymethyl)furan) [7,8], hydrodeoxygenation to methylfurans (2-methylfuran and 2,5-dimethylfuran) [9,10], and hydrogenative ring-rearrangement to cyclopentanones (cyclopentanone and 3-hydroxymethylcyclopentanone) and cyclopentanols (cyclopentanol and 3-hydroxymethylcyclopentanol) [11,12]. Among these products, cyclic compounds (cyclopentanones and cyclopentanols) are important multifunctional chemical intermediates used in the production of pharmaceuticals, insecticides, dye intermediates, herbicides, and fragrances. Currently, cyclopentanone is derived from the decarboxylation of petroleum-based 1,6-adipic acid, and cyclopentanol is derived from the hydrogenation of cyclopentanone. Meanwhile, large-scale production of 3-hydroxymethylcyclopentanone and 3-hydroxymethylcyclopentanol have not been reported. The synthesis of cyclopentanones and cyclopentanols from furfurals offers a crucial and sustainable pathway to produce high value-added chemicals and to expand the utilization of biomass resources. As is widely reported, the hydrogenative ring-rearrangement of furfurals to cyclic compounds must undergo a battery of C=O hydrogenation, ring-rearrangement, hydrogenation, and dehydration steps over reduced metals/solid acids in water solvent under a H2 pressure of 2.0–8.0 MPa and temperatures of 140–180 °C [13]. Many research groups have reported various acidic supports (such as metal–organic frameworks, metal oxides, zeolites, and carbon materials) loaded with various reduced metals (such as Pd, Pt, Ru, Au, Ni, Co) as bifunctional catalysts for the reactions [11–19]. Unfortunately, owing to the separations between hydrogenation sites (metal nanoparticles) and acidic sites (acidic support), their limited cooperativity often causes a slow transfer of intermediates between the active sites, and a large amount of C=O hydrogenated intermediates (i.e., furfuryl alcohol, 2,5-bis-(hydroxymethyl)furan) accumulates in the reaction system. To obtain high yields of cyclic products, the reaction suffers from harsh reaction conditions (such as elevated temperature, long time, and high catalyst doses). The weak synergism in bifunctional catalysis is a common problem with traditional metal/acidic support catalysts used in some tandem hydrogenation and acid-catalyzed reactions, such as, hydrogenative ring-opening, hydrogenative etherification and hydrodeoxygenation [3,7,9]. In addition to the low activity, some over-hydrogenated byproducts (i.e., tetrahydrofurfuryl alcohol and 2,5-bis(hydroxymethyl)tetrahydrofuran) are readily generated by furan ring hydrogenation, which decreases the selectivity for the target products. Hence, a powerful synergistic effect with bifunctional catalysis is desired to perform selective C=O hydrogenation and accelerate acid-catalyzed ring-rearrangement simultaneously. To strengthen the synergistic catalysis, we have recently reported an oxygen vacancy-promoted bifunctional catalysis over Pd/pyrochlore, and the near coexistence of hydrogenation and acid sites over metal phosphide nanoparticles [20,21]. However, it is still difficult to provide a high level of intimacy of hydrogenation-acid sites because of the robust roles of metal nanoparticles and acidic supports. Hydrogen spillover is a common phenomenon of noble metal/reductive metal oxides (such as Pt/WO3, Pt/WO3-ZrO2, Pt/SO4 2--ZrO2, Pt/MoO3-ZrO2, Ru/TiO2, Pt/CeO2), in which hydrogen is converted to protons (H+) via reduction of the transition metal support [22–26]. Recently, owing to its ability to increase hydrogen storage capacity and regulate surface electron distribution, hydrogen spillover has been widely investigated in various hydrogenation reactions, such as semi-hydrogenation of acetylene and phenylacetylene [27,28] and hydrogenation of benzene and 4-nitrophenol [29,30]. Especially, hydrogen spillover has exhibited selectivity in C=O hydrogenation with reactants containing both C=O and C=C groups (e.g., cinnamaldehyde), resulting from the ability of H+ ions formed in situ on the support surface to adsorb and activate the oxygen of C=O groups [31,32]. Meanwhile, the reduction of the transition metal support and generation of H+ cause transformation of the original Lewis acidity to Brønsted acidity. Theoretically, the acid transformation can modulate the acid-catalyzed activity of many reactions. However, their acid-catalyzed ability has been rarely reported, and achieved only limited success in alkane isomerization [22,23] and toluene disproportionation [33]. Notably, the Brønsted acid sites formed in situ have a high affinity for the noble metal sites. Therefore, hydrogen spillover may stimulate both C=O hydrogenation and ring-rearrangement steps, and the efficient synergism of bifunctional catalysis accelerates the synthesis of cyclopentanones and cyclopentanols by promoting catalytic activity and selectivity simultaneously. To our knowledge, this is the first report of the integration of the hydrogen spillover effect with bifunctional catalysis in complex biomass conversion reactions. Herein, a series of Pd/NiMoO4 catalysts with different Pd nanoparticle sizes have been fabricated based on the simple impregnation of different precursors (i.e., PdCl2 and Pd(CH3COO)2), followed by calcination with air and reduction with hydrogen. The Pd-NiMoO4 interface exhibits tailorable hydrogenation sites and acidic sites due to the hydrogen spillover induced by water. For the hydrogenative ring-rearrangement of furfurals, Pd-NiMoO4-Cl exhibits cyclopentanone compound yields of 56.3–85.3%, and Pd-NiMoO4-AC exhibits cyclopentanol compound yields of 65.4–85.2%. The catalytic performance of Pd/C and ATR-IR results suggest that hydrogen spillover strongly affects the adsorption configuration of reactants and the acidity of the catalyst, which further facilitates selectivity of C=O hydrogenation and activity of acid-catalyzed ring-rearrangement in the catalytic reactions. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials Furfural, furfuryl alcohol, nickel nitrate (Ni(NO3)2·6H2O), sodium molybdate (Na2MoO4·2H2O), palladium chloride (PdCl2), palladiumacetate (Pd(CH3COO)2), acetone, N,N-dimethyl formamide, and 5 wt%Pd/C were supplied by Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Company. 5-Hydroxymethyl furfural was attained from Beijing Coupling Technology Company. All the chemicals were utilized without further purification. 2.2 Preparation of Pd/NiMoO4 NiMoO4 was synthesized through a simple hydrothermal method. Briefly, 25 mL of 0.1 mol/L Ni(NO3)2·6H2O aqueous solution were added in 25 mL of 0.1 mol/L Na2MoO4·2H2O aqueous solution under vigorous stirring for 10 min. Then, the mixture was transferred to a 100 mL Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave, and heated at 150 °C for 6 h. The resultant yellow solid NiMoO4 was obtained by filtration, washed by water, and dried at 60 °C for 12 h. Pd/NiMoO4 was prepared via an incipient method. Typically, 1 g of NiMoO4, 0.017 g of PdCl2 or 0.021 g of Pd(CH3COO)2, and 20 mL of acetone was mixed for 10 min and heated at 60 °C to thoroughly evaporate acetone. If not mentioned, the Pd/NiMoO4 was obtained by calcinations at 400 °C for 2 h under an air atmosphere and reduced at 200 °C for 1 h in 5 %H2/Ar atmosphere. The Pd content on the support surface is 1.0 wt%. The Pd/NiMoO4 with Pd(CH3COO)2 and PdCl2 as Pd precursors were labeled as Pd/NiMoO4-AC and Pd/NiMoO4-Cl, respectively. 2.3 Catalyst characterizations The crystal structure of the catalyst was detailed on a Panalytical Empyrean diffractometer with a Cu target and Cu-Kα radiation through powder X-ray diffraction (XRD). The Pore Volume and the specific surface areas (BET) were achieved on an ASAP 2046 surface analyzer via accomplishing N2 adsorption-desorption at −196 °C. The X-ray photoemission spectroscopy (XPS) data were implemented exploiting an ESCALAB 250Xi instrument furnished with a monochromatic Al anode X-ray gun. The morphology and Pd nanoparticle size of the catalysts were revealed exploiting a JEM-2100 transmission electron microscope (TEM). The content of Ni, Mo, Pd was carried out on a PerkinElmer Optima 8000 spectrometer exploiting Inductively Coupled Plasma Optical Emission Spectrometry (ICP-OES). The acid properties were calculated via infrared spectroscopy with adsorbed pyridine depleting a Bruker VERTEX 70 spectrometer. The hydrogen activation ability was distinguished by H2-D2 exchange. The 4 mg of 5 wt%Pd/C or 20 mg Pd/NiMoO4 was pretreated in a fixed bed reactor at 150 °C for 1 h, equipped with an 8 mm (inner diameter) quartz tube under 30 mL/min of N2. After cooling to 70 °C, the gas was substituted to a mixture of H2 (6 mL/min), D2 (6 mL/min), and N2 (18 mL/min), and next execute the H2-D2 exchange reaction. The outlet gases were checked via an online MS. 2.4 Catalytic reactions The hydrogenative ring-rearrangement of bioderived furfurals was accomplished in a 100 mL batch autoclave equipped with a mechanical stirrer (Anhui Kemi Machinery Technology Co., LTD). Typically, 10.4 mmol of furfurals, 0.1 g of Pd/NiMoO4 or 0.02 g of 5 wt%Pd/C, and 40 mL of water, were added into the reactor under string. Before the reaction, the air in the reactor was exchanged with H2 for 6 times. Then, the mixtures were heated to 150 °C under 4.0 MPa H2 pressure, and next periodically sampled with 1.0 mL after reaching the target reaction time. Subsequently, the reaction mixtures were separated with 1.0 mL of ethyl acetate, and 10 μL of N,N-dimethyl formamide was introduced as an internal standard substance. The reaction mixture was qualitatively analyzed by an Agilent 6890 N GC/5973 MS detector, and next quantitatively analyzed by a Trace 1300 gas chromatograph equipped with a TG-WAXMS capillary column (30 m × 0.32 mm). The rest of the carbon loss was described as humins. The adsorption experiment of all catalysts was performed in a flask. A mixture of CPO (0.312 mmol) and FA (0.728 mmol) and 0.1 g of Pd/NiMoO4 or 0.02 g of 5 wt%Pd/C was stirred in 30 mL of H2O at 30 °C, and then sampled periodically, and the concentration of the reactant was determined by a Hitachi U-3010 UV–vis spectrometer. 2.5 In situ attenuated total reflection infrared (ATR-IR) measurements The ATR-IR spectrometer is placed on the Nicolet iS50 spectrometer, which contains a heating chamber with a CaF window a high-sensitivity MCT detector. Primarily, the catalyst was suspended into ethanol solution, afterward the suspension was brought onto the surface of the diamond probe in the instrument, dried at 100 °C. The ATR-IR spectrum was documented by an average of 32 scans with a resolution of 2 cm−1. In order to be as consistent with the experimental conditions as possible, the catalyst was activated in a 5% H2/Ar atmosphere at 150 °C for 1 h, documented the background spectrum, and next the substrate was added. Liquid furfural was purged to the surface of the catalyst by 40 mL/min Ar gas flow. At 150 °C, the catalyst was adsorbed by furfural for 30 min, and later the physically adsorbed furfural will be eliminated by continuous Ar gas flow. Ultimately, the original solid–liquid surface ATR-IR spectroscopy was documented. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Structural characteristics of Pd/NiMoO4 As shown in Fig. 1 A, the XRD diffraction peaks for NiMoO4 and the corresponding Pd/NiMoO4 matched well with standard crystallographic data (PDF#86–361) [34]. The absence of Pd peaks after the introduction of 1 wt% of Pd nanoparticles indicates that Pd nanoparticles are highly dispersed. NiMoO4 has a monoclinic phase with space group C2/m (Fig. S1), in which Mo6+ and Ni2+ atoms occupy the tetrahedral and octahedral sites, respectively. The ICP-OES results show that the molar ratios of Ni:Mo are approximately 1:1 for all catalysts (Table 1 ), which is consistent with the corresponding theoretical stoichiometric values. The Cl content is undetected due to the thermal decomposition of PdCl2 [20]. N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms for all catalysts display type IV isotherms with an H3 hysteresis loop (Fig. 1B). They possess identical texture structures and BET specific surface areas ranging from 30-40 m2/g. The HRTEM image in Fig. 2 A shows representative polycrystals with two adjacent lattice fringes of 0.31 nm, which are equivalent to those of the (220) crystal face of NiMoO4. Additionally, the size distribution of Pd nanoparticles (Fig. 2B, C) for Pd/NiMoO4-AC was smaller than that for Pd/NiMoO4-Cl (1.8 vs 3.5 nm) because Pd(CH3COO)2 is more easily converted to PdO during calcination by air, and the oxide-oxide interaction causes a uniform distribution of Pd over NiMoO4 after reduction by H2 [35]. 3.2 Synthesis of cyclopentanone and cyclopentanol from furfural As mentioned above, the hydrogenative ring-rearrangement of furfural (FFA) to cyclic compounds (cyclopentanone CPO, cyclopentanol CPL) consists of C=O hydrogenation to furfuryl alcohol (FA), ring-rearrangement to 4-hydroxy-2-cyclopentenone (HCPEO), and subsequent dehydration and hydrogenation reactions (Fig. 3 A). Fig. 3B, C, D shows the temporal evolution of intermediate and product concentrations over Pd-NiMoO4-AC and Pd-NiMoO4-Cl, with those for Pd/C provided for comparison. The HCPEO intermediate was formed at trace levels, indicating that the C=O hydrogenation of FFA, acid-catalyzed ring-rearrangement of FA, and C=O hydrogenation of CPO are rate-limiting steps. Except for CPL and CPO, some tetrahydrofurfuryl alcohol (THFA) and humin are produced via the full hydrogenation of FA and polymerization of reactive intermediates, respectively. The H2 18O isotope labeling experiment indicates that the positions of the CPL (m/z = 88) and CPO ion peaks (m/z = 86) are higher than those of their counterparts made in H2 16O solvent (m/z = 86, 84), which indicates that the 18O of water plays a role in ring-rearrangement reactions (Fig. S2). Blank experiment without catalyst and pure NiMoO4 cannot catalyze the hydrogenation of furfural, indicating that Pd nanoparticles are the only sites active for hydrogenation (Fig. 3E). For comparison, all Pd-based catalysts show complete conversion of FFA. Pd/C shows a 62.6% selectivity of THFA after 6 h, and only 13.7% selectivity for CPO was obtained due to the lack of acidic sites (Fig. 3B). Both Pd/NiMoO4-AC and Pd/NiMoO4-Cl exhibited powerful bifunctional catalysis with efficient syntheses of cyclic compounds, and the synthesis of THFA byproducts was largely inhibited. Differently, the main product over Pd-NiMoO4-AC is CPL, with 85.2% selectivity, but over Pd/NiMoO4-Cl it is CPO, with 85.3% selectivity. Curiously, the CPO in situ generated cannot be converted to CPL over Pd/C or Pd/NiMoO4-Cl by extending the reaction time to 24 h, although this seems to require only C=O hydrogenation (Fig. 3E). Finally, a CPO yield of 85.3% and a CPL yield of 85.2% were obtained over Pd/NiMoO4-Cl and Pd/NiMoO4-AC, respectively. The NiMoO4-based catalysts show comparable CPO and CPL synthesis efficiency with previous reports under a relatively short reaction time, low reaction temperature (Table S1) [12,16,18–20,36–42]. Besides, compared with our previous reports catalyzed by MOF-based and pyrochlore-based catalysts, the NiMoO4-based catalysts show a comparative catalytic performance, despite the Pd amount is only one-fifth of the previous reports [20,36–38]. Furthermore, the catalyst was easily separated by filtration and was reused after washing with water. After 4 cycles, the catalyst showed a robust catalytic performance with no apparent degradation of activity and selectivity (Fig. S3). XRD, N2 adsorption-desorption, and ICP-OES characteristics of the spent catalyst demonstrate the outstanding stability of Pd/NiMoO4 (Fig. S4, Table S2). To verify the catalytic hydrogenation activity of different catalysts, a kinetic study of FFA conversion was conducted. The hydrogenation kinetics followed pseudo first-order kinetics (Fig. S5A). Combined with the result of H2-D2 exchange, this observation indicates that the size of the Pd nanoparticles strongly affects their activity in H2 activation (Fig. 4 A). H2 activation on the metal surface is the first step in the hydrogenation reaction, and the catalytic hydrogenation rate constants strongly depend on H2 activation ability: Pd/NiMoO4-AC (0.87 h−1, 1.8 nm) > Pd/C (0.71 h−1, 3.4 nm) > Pd/NiMoO4-Cl (0.65 h−1, 3.5 nm) (Fig. 4B, S6). To verify the acid-catalyzed ability of different catalysts, a kinetic study of FA conversion was also conducted, and the ring-rearrangement was found to proceed via pseudo first-order kinetics (Figs. S5B, C). To eliminate the potential influence of furan ring hydrogenation, ring-rearrangement was first conducted under a N2 atmosphere. The blank experiment without a catalyst showed a slow conversion of FA, which was catalyzed by protons formed by in situ dissociation of water [43,44]. The ring-rearrangement rate constants followed the order Pd/C (0.10 h−1) < Pd/NiMoO4-Cl (0.41 h−1) ≈ Pd/NiMoO4-AC (0.42 h−1) (Fig. 4C). Interestingly, under a H2 atmosphere, the kinetic constants of Pd/C and Pd/NiMoO4-Cl raised slightly, whereas that of Pd/NiMoO4-AC was enhanced approximately 1.6 times. The order has been changed to Pd/C (0.11 h−1) < Pd/NiMoO4-Cl (0.46 h−1) < Pd/NiMoO4-AC (0.68 h−1). This result indicates that H2 not only serves as a reductant for the hydrogenation steps but also as an acid promoter for the ring-rearrangement steps. 3.3 Synthesis of 3-hydroxymethylcyclopentanone and 3-hydroxymethylcyclopentanol from 5-hydroxymethylfurfural Analogous to furfural, the hydrogenative ring-rearrangement of 5-hydroxymethylfurfural (HMF) to 3-hydroxymethylcyclopentanone (HCPO) and 3-hydroxymethylcyclopentanol (HCPL) involves C=O hydrogenation to form 2,5-bis(hydroxymethyl)furan (BHF), hydrolytic ring-opening and hydrogenation to form 1-hydroxyl-2,5-hexanedione (HHD), intramolecular aldol condensation to form 4-hydroxy-4-hydroxymethyl-2-cyclopentanone (HHCPN) and subsequent dehydration and hydrogenation reactions (Fig. 5 A). Additionally, 2,5-dihydroxymethyl tetrahydrofuran (THBHF) can be generated by the full hydrogenation route. The temporal evolution of the product distribution shows high concentrations of BHF, HHD, and HCPO, indicating that the C=O hydrogenation of HMF, hydrolysis ring-opening of BHF, intramolecular aldol steps of HHD, and C=O hydrogenation of HCPO were rate-limiting steps. Identically, the conversion of HMF (Fig. 5B, C, D, E) follows the order Pd/NiMoO4-AC (99.9%) > Pd/C (98.1%) > Pd/NiMoO4-Cl (97.4%), and the selectivity for cyclic compounds follows the order Pd/NiMoO4-AC (HCPL 65.4%, HCPO 3.6%) > Pd/NiMoO4-Cl (HCPL 3.6%, HCPO 57.8%) > Pd/C (HCPL 0.1%, HCPO 1.8%). As a result, Pd/NiMoO4-AC and Pd/NiMoO4-Cl exhibit the main product HCPL with 65.4% yield and HCPO with 56.3% yield, respectively. 3.4 Identification of the reaction mechanism To explore the reaction mechanism, three main issues related to rate-limiting steps need to be addressed (Fig. 6 C). First, selective C=O hydrogenation rather than hydrogenation of both the furan ring and C=O group is essential for the synthesis of cyclic compounds. The mechanism for adsorption of the reactant determines the hydrogenation route: the perpendicular adsorption of FFA (selective adsorption of the C=O group) promotes the selective hydrogenation of the C=O group, whereas horizontal adsorption (adsorption of both furan ring and C=O group) promotes the full hydrogenation of both furan ring and C=O group [45]. ATR-IR (In situ attenuated total reflection infrared) was used to study the interaction of FFA with the catalyst at the molecular level. The IR signals of the parent FFA at 1022 and 1682 cm−1 were attributed to the stretching vibrations of the furan ring and C=O group, respectively (Fig. 6A) [46]. The interactions of FFA with all catalysts caused redshifts of the furan ring peak to 910 cm−1 and the C=O peak to 1652 cm−1, indicating that both the furan ring and C=O were in contact with the catalyst surface. To eliminate H2O-mediated solvent effects on selective hydrogenation of furfural, cyclohexane was used as the solvent [47]. The horizontal adsorption configuration of FFA on parent Pd/NiMoO4-AC caused high selectivity for THFA (Fig. S7). However, the adsorption configuration is inconsistent with the abovementioned catalytic results for Pd/NiMoO4-AC, and we wondered if the structure of the active site was modified by water and H2. Therefore, water and H2 were used to pretreat these catalysts under the in-situ reaction conditions for 6 h, except without the addition of FFA. Treated Pd/C still showed a horizontal adsorption configuration, whereas treated Pd/NiMoO4-Cl and Pd/NiMoO4-AC showed a perpendicular adsorption configuration in which the peak of the C=O group was shifted to 1661 cm−1 but the peak of the furan ring was unchanged. To further illustrate the interaction of the furan ring and C=O group with these catalysts, we used FA and CPO as probes (Fig. 6B, S8). Competitive adsorption experiments demonstrated that the furan ring preferred to react with the parent catalysts rather than treated ones, giving the following order for FA adsorption quality: parent Pd/C (42.1 wt%) ≈ treated Pd/C (42.0 wt%) > parent Pd/NiMoO4-Cl (39.9 wt%) ≈ parent Pd/NiMoO4-AC (39.8 wt%) > treated Pd/NiMoO4-Cl (18.2 wt%) > treated Pd/NiMoO4-AC (17.5 wt%). In contrast, the adsorption ability of the C=O group is opposite with the order of CPO adsorption quality: parent Pd/C (17.1 wt%) ≈ treated Pd/C (16.9 wt%) < parent Pd/NiMoO4-Cl (20.2 wt%) ≈ parent Pd/NiMoO4-AC (20.4 wt%) < treated Pd/NiMoO4-Cl (42.1 wt%) < treated Pd/NiMoO4-AC (44.3 wt%). XPS was used to investigate the modification of surface properties (Fig. 7 A, B, C, S9). For the parent Pd/NiMoO4-AC and Pd/NiMoO4-Cl, the Pd 3d spectra show 3d3/2 and 3d5/2 peaks for metallic Pd0 (centered at 340.8 and 335.1 eV), and the Mo 3d spectrum shows 3d3/2 and 3d5/2 peaks for Mo6+ (at 235.5 and 232.4 eV) [48,49]. The Ni 2p spectrum displays Ni 2p3/2 and Ni 2p1/2 peaks for Ni2+ (at 857.2 and 881.4 eV). Moreover, the O 1s spectrum exhibits two peaks centered at 530.0 and 531.7 eV, which are ascribed to lattice oxygen (OI) and oxygen species adsorbed on the sites of oxygen vacancies (OII) [50]. As shown in Fig. S9, no peaks appear at 200 eV, indicating the absence Cl element on Pd/NiMoO4-Cl. However, after treatment, the Pd 3d peak shifted slightly to higher binding energy, whereas Ni 2p peak shifted to lower energy. New peaks for Mo5+ and hydroxyl groups appeared in the Mo 3d and O 1s spectra, respectively. Meanwhile, the intensity of OII peak became significantly stronger. This can be attributed to the occurrence of hydrogen spillover. Hydrogen is homogeneously dissociated to form hydrogen atoms on the Pd nanoparticle surface, which migrate to the oxygen ions and reduce the metal ions on the support. Meanwhile, the surface oxygen vacancies can trap water molecules, which donate a proton to a neighboring surface oxygen anion [51]. It results in the generation of hydroxyl species (OII and OIII) on the NiMoO4 surface. Because Pd is less electronegative than hydrogen, Pd transfers electron density to the hydrogen atom [52,53]. Additionally, the XPS data for the recycled catalysts also exhibited the same result as the treated samples (Fig. S10). Because the synthesis of Pd/NiMoO4 proceeded with reduction by H2, H2 cannot spill over with Pd/NiMoO4 unless water is involved in the process. In previous reports, Yang and Resasco’s group revealed that water plays an important role in reducing the diffusion barrier of active hydrogen atoms [47,54]. This water-mediated hydrogen spillover phenomenon was more pronounced on Pd-NiMoO4-AC because the smaller Pd nanoparticles exhibited closer interfacial contact between Pd and NiMoO4. Considering the XPS results and control experiments using Pd/NiMoO4 before and after pretreatment, we propose that the OH+-H--Pd structure prepared in situ is the C=O hydrogenation active site that selectively fixes and activates the asymmetric C=O rather than the furan ring [55]. Second, the synthesis of cyclic compounds requires efficient acidic sites for the ring-rearrangement steps. As has been noted, the activity of Pd/NiMoO4-AC and Pd/NiMoO4-Cl in acid-catalyzed processes was obviously enhanced under a H2 atmosphere compared with a N2 atmosphere. Under a N2 atmosphere, treated Pd/NiMoO4-AC and Pd/NiMoO4-Cl catalysts exhibited ring-rearrangement rate constants similar to those seen for the in-situ reaction conditions, indicating that hydrogen spillover affected the acidity of catalysts. FTIR spectra with adsorbed pyridine were used to characterize the changes in acidity. IR peaks at 1450 and 1540 cm−1 are attributed to pyridine chemisorbed on the Lewis and Brønsted acid sites (Fig. 8 A). These parent Pd/NiMoO4 catalysts exhibited pure Lewis acidity resulting from the exposed Mo6+ on the surface. After the water and H2 treatment, the peak for Lewis acid sites was weakened, and the peak for Brønsted acid sites appeared. These results indicate that the proton generated adjacent to an oxygen ion served as a Brønsted acid site. The concentration of Brønsted and Lewis acid sites was calculated according to the Emeis equation [56]. The total amounts of acid in these Pd/NiMoO4 catalysts were basically equivalent. The amounts of Lewis acid and Brønsted acidity of catalysts exhibited the following orders (Table 2 ): parent Pd/NiMoO4-Cl (108.5 µmol/g) ≈ parent Pd/NiMoO4-AC (108.7 µmol/g) > treated Pd/NiMoO4-Cl (93.8 µmol/g) > treated Pd/NiMoO4-AC (73.2 µmol/g), and parent Pd/NiMoO4-Cl (1.3 µmol/g) ≈ parent Pd/NiMoO4-OAC (1.4 µmol/g) < treated Pd/NiMoO4-Cl (8.9 µmol/g) < treated Pd/NiMoO4-AC (40.2 µmol/g). Pd/NiMoO4-AC with a high Pd dispersion exhibited a more obvious transformation of acid types under in situ reaction conditions. To better investigate the relationship between acidity and acid-catalyzed ability, the ring-rearrangement of FA was conducted using pyridine and 2,6-dimethylpyridine as in situ titrants. Pyridine can poison both Lewis and Brønsted acid sites, whereas 2,6-dimethylpyridine selectively binds Brønsted acid sites [57]. Pyridine deactivates acid sites of Pd/NiMoO4-Cl and Pd/NiMoO4-AC, and the ring-rearrangement rate constants are significantly decreased from 0.43, 0.68 h−1 to 0.15, 0.13 h−1, respectively (Fig. 8B, S11). However, after titration of 2,6-dimethylpyridine, the reaction rate of Pd/NiMoO4-Cl is slightly decreased to 0.31 h−1, and that of Pd/NiMoO4-Cl is dropped to 0.25 h−1. These results indicate both Lewis and Brønsted acidity can catalyze the ring-rearrangement reaction. However, Brønsted acidic site has a stronger acid-catalyzed ability than Lewis acidic site. The in-situ transformation of Lewis to Brønsted acidic site was conducive to the protonation and dehydration of FA, which largely accelerated the ring-rearrangement steps [58–60]. Third, high selectivity for CPL was observed with Pd/NiMoO4-AC, whereas high selectivity for CPO was observed with Pd/NiMoO4-Cl. Notably, commercial cyclopentanol is obtained from the hydrogenation of cyclopentanone, which indicates that the former is more valuable than the latter. The result for Pd/C agrees with those of previous work without the production of CPL [11]. When pure CPO was used as a feedstock, both Pd/NiMoO4-AC and Pd/NiMoO4-Cl catalyzed the hydrogenation to CPL, and Pd/NiMoO4-AC outperformed Pd/NiMoO4-Cl (0.37 vs 0.28 h−1) with a higher hydrogenation rate due to the abundant OH+-H-Pd sites available for the adsorption and activation of C=O groups (Figs. 9. , S12). However, when a mixture of CPO and FA was used as feedstock, Pd/NiMoO4-AC exhibited the ability to hydrogenate the C=O of CPO, but Pd/NiMoO4-Cl did not. To investigate the effect of Pd nanoparticle size, Pd/NiMoO4 with a larger Pd size (3.0 nm) was prepared by calcinations at 600 °C for 2 h using Pd(CH3COO)2 as a precursor (Fig. S13). It shows a 75.5% selectivity for CPO in the hydrogenative ring-rearrangement of FFA. These results indicate that the furan ring groups in the reactant or intermediates (such as FFA and FA) were strongly attached to the large particle Pd surface and that this hindered further hydrogenation of CPO. Pd/NiMoO4-AC exhibited a higher CPL yield resulting from the low metal surface area and rich Pd-NiMoO4 interface, which are not beneficial for the adsorption of the furan ring. These results prove that the excellent catalytic performance of Pd/NiMoO4 resulted from its high capacity for both hydrogenation and acid catalysis, which are derived from the water-mediated hydrogen spillover effect. Because water is a common solvent in biomass conversion, this catalytic system opens a new door leading toward high efficiency in bifunctional catalysis via a water-promoted mechanism. 4 Conclusions We have discovered an efficient strategy for promoting hydrogenative ring-rearrangement reactions over Pd/NiMoO4 catalysts by in situ water-mediated hydrogen spillover. Hydrogen spillover was controlled by tuning the Pd nanoparticle size, which regulated both the adsorption configuration of the reactant and the acidity of the catalysts and further determined the reaction routes of furfurals. Pd/C exhibited over-hydrogenated byproducts (tetrahydrofurfuryl alcohol and 2,5-bis(hydroxymethyl)tetrahydrofuran) as the main product, due to the horizontal adsorption of furfurals. However, Pd/NiMoO4-Cl and Pd/NiMoO4-AC exhibited cyclopentanones yields and a cyclopentanols yield exceeding 60%, as a result of the perpendicular adsorption. This work provides an efficient synthetic path for cyclic compounds and shows an interesting strategy for activating bifunctional catalysis with a hydrogen spillover mechanism. coredata.dc:description: Upgrading bioderived furfurals (furfural, 5-hydroxymethylfurfural) to cyclopentanones (cyclopentanone, 3-hydroxymethylcyclopentanone) and cyclopentanols (cyclopentanol, 3-hydroxymethylcyclopentanol) is a representative bifunctional catalytic process in biomass conversion. Here, a class of Pd/NiMoO4 catalysts (Pd/NiMoO4-Cl, Pd/NiMoO4-AC) with low Pd loading (1.0 wt%) and different Pd dispersion are synthesized. The hydrogenation active sites and acidic sites of catalysts were adjusted by a water-mediated hydrogen spillover process. 56.3–85.3% yields of cyclopentanones and 65.4–85.2% yields of cyclopentanols were obtained by hydrogenative ring-rearrangement route of furfurals over Pd/NiMoO4-Cl and Pd/NiMoO4-AC, respectively. Over-hydrogenated byproducts (tetrahydrofurfuryl alcohol, 2,5-bis(hydroxymethyl)tetrahydrofuran) with a yield above 54% were generated by a full hydrogenation route over Pd/C. The difference in catalytic performance is results from alteration of the adsorption configurations of reactants and the transformation of Lewis acid sites to Brønsted acid sites by hydrogen spillover. This work presents an effective strategy for governing reaction routes and enhancing bifunctional catalysis with a hydrogen spillover mechanism.
coredata.dc:title: Water-mediated hydrogen spillover accelerates hydrogenative ring-rearrangement of furfurals to cyclic compounds
